questions.text:
A 46-year-old diabetic patient presented with fever, malaise, and a productive cough. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Patchy infiltrates as seen in pyogenic pneumonia
Interstitial infiltrates as seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia
Hilar lymphadenopathy with infiltrates as seen in malignancy
Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the upper segment of the lower lobe and posterior segment of the upper lobe

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Patchy infiltrates as seen in pyogenic pneumonia

 

Explanation:

  • Patchy infiltrates are more characteristic of atypical pneumonia, such as Mycoplasma pneumonia or viral infections.
  • Pyogenic (community-acquired) pneumonia more commonly presents with lobar consolidation rather than patchy infiltrates.

 

Interstitial infiltrates in Mycoplasma pneumonia (Option B): Mycoplasma pneumonia typically presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy with infiltrates in malignancy (Option C): Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in malignancies such as lung cancer, though it is not relevant to the acute presentation in this case.

 

Aspiration pneumonia distribution (Option D): Aspiration pneumonia commonly affects the upper segment of the lower lobe and posterior segment of the upper lobe due to gravitational factors when the patient is supine.

questions.text: What should be your subsequent course of action for the patient, who has been intubated and his X-ray as depicted in the radiograph?

choices.text: Start antibiotics and send and samples for culture

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ultrasound-guided aspiration

Explanation:

  • As the patient's chest X-ray reveals a significant amount of fluid accumulation on the left thorax and as the patient is also intubated, ultrasound-guided aspiration may be a reasonable next step. It is often done to improve respiratory function and prevent complications associated with accumulation of fluid in the lungs.
  • Ultrasound serves a complementary role in chest imaging, particularly in evaluating fluid collections.

Applications of Ultrasound:

  • Pleural Effusion: Used for detection and guiding the drainage of fluid collections.
  • Pericardial Effusion: Evaluates the presence of fluid around the heart and for assessing cardiac function.

 

Suctioning (Option A) is a routine procedure used to clear the airway of secretions or foreign material. While suctioning may be necessary for some intubated patients, it is not a next specific step. The appropriateness of suctioning would depend on the patient's clinical condition and the presence of indications for suctioning.

Chest physiotherapy (Option B) techniques, such as postural drainage, percussion, and vibration, are often used to help mobilize secretions and improve airway clearance. While these techniques may be beneficial in certain cases, they are not the next specific steps for this patient.

Starting antibiotics and sending samples for culture (Option C) may be appropriate in certain situations, such as suspected or confirmed respiratory infection. However, the decision to start antibiotics and send samples for culture should be based on a comprehensive evaluation of the patient's clinical presentation, including signs and symptoms of infection. It cannot be determined solely based on the information of an X-ray finding.

questions.text: A 50-year-old individual who is a chronic smoker came with complaints of recurrent episodes of coughing up blood without any accompanying symptoms of fever or weight loss. On chest x-ray there were no abnormalities seen, and the sputum test is also negative for acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Which of the following options could be the next effective diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CT

Explanation:

  • CT chest (computed tomography) is the next most useful diagnostic investigation. CT scan provides detailed imaging of the lungs and can help identify subtle abnormalities that may not be visible on a chest X-ray. It can detect small nodules, bronchial wall thickening, or other structural changes in the lungs that could be contributing to the hemoptysis. CT scan is commonly used in the evaluation of hemoptysis, especially when the chest X-ray is normal or inconclusive.

Computed Tomography (CT)

  • CT scans are the preferred imaging modality for various lung pathologies due to their ability to produce detailed cross-sectional images of the chest. This high-resolution imaging allows for the precise visualization of thoracic structures.

Multiple Windows for Enhanced Visualization:

Lung Window: Optimizes the visibility of lung parenchyma and vascular structures.

Mediastinal Window: Ideal for assessing soft tissues in the mediastinum, including lymph nodes and masses.

Bone Window: Focuses on cortical bone to evaluate bony structures.

Types of CT Scans:

  • Non-Contrast CT (NCCT): Often sufficient for initial evaluations of lung pathologies.
  • Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Indicated in cases involving space-occupying lesions, infections, or inflammatory processes. CECT is particularly beneficial for detecting filling defects, which are crucial in diagnosing vascular conditions such as pulmonary embolism and aortic aneurysms.

  Normal CT Abdomen

Normal CECT Abdomen

Common Thoracic Pathologies Diagnosed with CT:

  • Pulmonary Embolism: CECT is effective in visualizing filling defects within pulmonary arteries.
  • Interstitial Lung Disease: High-resolution CT (HRCT) is essential for characterizing various interstitial lung diseases.
  • Mediastinal Masses: CT aids in evaluating lymphadenopathy and tumors within the mediastinum.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a cough with yellowish sputum. Auscultation revealed bronchial breath sounds. He is hemodynamically stable and not confused. On examination, his respiratory rate is 20/min, and his blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Lab reports show urea levels of 44 mg/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Given antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation
Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation
Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms, such as productive cough, tachypnea, and hypotension, align with the diagnosis of pneumonia.
  • The CURB-65 score of this patient is 2 (age >/= 65 and urea > 19mg/dl); hence, the patient can be considered for admission to a non-ICU setting for further management.

Treatment for Lobar Pneumonia

  • Treatment depends on severity; assess if inpatient or outpatient management is needed.
  • CURB-65 Score: Used to stratify patients with the following factors:

CURB-65

Symptom

Score

(C) Confusion

1

(U) Urea: BUN >19mg/dL (>7 mmol/L)

1

(R) Respiratory rate ≥30/min

1

(B) Blood Pressure – Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg or diastolic BP ≤60 mmHg

1

(65) Age ≥65 years

1
  • Hospitalization Criteria:
    • CURB-65 score 1 or 2: Indicates hospitalization
    • A score ≥3: Indicates ICU admission and more intensive therapy. (Option B and C)
  • Empiric Therapy:
    • Outpatient: (Option A)
      • When no symptoms in the CURB-65 scoring system are present.
      • No comorbidities: Monotherapy with macrolides (Azithromycin, Clarithromycin).
      • With comorbidities (chronic lung/heart disease, diabetes, smoking, HIV): Newer Fluoroquinolones (Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin, Gemifloxacin) or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., Amoxicillin) and a macrolide.
    • Inpatient Non-ICU:
      • Newer Fluoroquinolones (Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin) alone or a combination of beta-lactam (e.g., Ampicillin, Ceftriaxone) and a macrolide.
    • Inpatient ICU:
      • Combination of macrolide (Azithromycin) or newer fluoroquinolone (Levofloxacin) with beta-lactam (e.g., Ampicillin-sulbactam, Ertapenem).
      • If risk of aspiration, consider ampicillin-sulbactam or ertapenem; for Pseudomonas infection, use anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam (e.g., Piperacillin-tazobactam) with anti-pseudomonal fluoroquinolone (e.g., Ciprofloxacin).
      • For MRSA, add vancomycin or linezolid.
  • Duration of Therapy: Typically 5 to 7 days, extended if clinical response is delayed.
  • Influenza Treatment: All hospitalized patients testing positive for influenza should receive Oseltamivir, regardless of illness onset.

questions.text: A woman with hysteria who was hyperventilating developed carpo-pedal spasms. What could be the likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

The clinical features of hyperventilation leading to carpal spasm are caused due to respiratory alkalosis.

  • Respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is a decrease in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels in the blood, leading to an increase in alkalinity.
  • Hyperventilation causes excessive elimination of carbon dioxide, leading to decreased blood CO2 levels. This results in respiratory alkalosis

Clinical features of respiratory alkalosis will include:

  • Tachypnea
  • Symptoms of hypocapnia
  • Paresthesias from decreased ionized calcium due to alkalemia
  • Reduced cerebral blood flow from hypocapnia
  • Decreased ionized calcium causing tetany/carpopedal spasms

Respiratory alkalosis- Clinical Features & Management

Category

Features

Cause

Neurological
  • Dizziness
  • Mental confusion
  • Paresthesias
  • Circumoral numbness
  • Seizures (severe cases)
  • Due to reduced cerebral blood flow
  • From rapid ↓ PaCO2
  • May occur without hypoxemia

Cardiovascular
  • Chest tightness/pain
  • Palpitations
  • Arrhythmias
  • Possible ECG changes
  • Due to coronary vasoconstriction
  • ↓ ionized calcium effects
  • Bohr effect on O2 delivery

Neuromuscular
  • Carpopedal spasms
  • Tetany
  • Muscle twitching
  • Weakness
  • From ↓ ionized calcium
  • Enhanced nerve excitability
  • Similar to hypocalcemia

Laboratory
  • ↑ pH
  • ↓ PaCO2
  • ↓ Ionized calcium
  • ↓ K+, ↓ PO4
  • Acute: ↓ HCO3- by 2 mEq/L per 10 mmHg ↓ PaCO2
  • Chronic: ↓ HCO3- by 4-5 mEq/L per 10 mmHg ↓ PaCO2
  • Electrolyte shifts into cells

Management

Underlying Disease:

  • Treat primary condition
  • Address anxiety if present
  • Manage sepsis if present
 

Hyperventilation Syndrome:

  • Reassurance
  • Rebreathing techniques
  • Paper bag breathing if needed
  • β-blockers if needed
  • Primary focus on the underlying cause
  • Avoid sedatives for anxiety
  • Monitor during mechanical ventilation
  • Adjust ventilator settings if needed
  • Regular monitoring of blood gases
  • Address psychological factors

Incorrect Options:

Respiratory acidosis (Option A) results from impaired ventilation due to pulmonary disease, respiratory muscle fatigue, or abnormalities in ventilatory control. Some examples of these are drugs, alcohol, motor neuron diseases, skeletal muscle disease, etc.

Metabolic acidosis (Option B) is caused by methanol, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, iron tablets, isoniazid, etc and not by hyperventilation.

Metabolic alkalosis (Option D) is caused by exogenous bicarbonate loads, hypertension, K+ deficiency, mineralocorticoid excess, etc.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman is admitted due to persistent vomiting. She gives a history of consuming food from outside. On evaluation, her blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following findings. What is the cause of her ABG findings?

pH - 7.52

HCO3- 30 meq/L

PaCO2 - 20 mmHg

Na- 123 mEq/L

K- 3.2 mEq/L

CI- 67 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Persistent vomiting

Explanation:

  • The arterial blood gas shows an elevated pH (7.52) and increased bicarbonate (30 meq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia further support this diagnosis. The cause of this in the given scenario is persistent vomiting (hypochloremia).

Metabolic Alkalosis

  • Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an increase in arterial pH, elevated serum bicarbonate [HCO3−], and increased PaCO2​ due to compensatory hypoventilation.
  • Often presents with hypochloremia and hypokalemia.
  • Occurs as a mixed disorder with respiratory or metabolic acidosis or alkalosis.
  • Causes
    • Exogenous Bicarbonate Loads
      • Acute alkali administration
      • Milk-alkali syndrome
    • Effective ECFV Contraction (Normotension, K+ Deficiency, Secondary Hyperreninemic Hyperaldosteronism)
      • Gastrointestinal Origin: Vomiting, gastric aspiration, congenital chloridorrhea, gastro cystoplasty, villous adenoma
      • Renal Origin: Diuretic use (thiazides, loop diuretics), post hypercapnic state, hypercalcemia/hypoparathyroidism, recovery from acidosis, non-resorbable anions (e.g., penicillin), Mg²⁺ deficiency, K⁺ depletion, Bartter's syndrome, Gitelman's syndrome
    • ECFV Expansion, Hypertension, K+ Deficiency, and Mineralocorticoid Excess
      • High Renin: Renal artery stenosis, accelerated hypertension, renin-secreting tumour, estrogen therapy
      • Low Renin: Primary aldosteronism (adenoma, hyperplasia, carcinoma), adrenal enzyme defects (11β-hydroxylase, 17α-hydroxylase deficiency), Cushing’s syndrome, substances like liquorice, carbenoxolone
    • Genetic Sodium Channel Mutation (Liddle's Syndrome)
    • A gain-of-function mutation in the distal convoluted tubule, causing ECFV expansion, hypertension, K⁺ deficiency, and hypo-reninemic-hypoaldosteronism
  • Clinical Features
    • Neurological: Mental confusion, obtundation, potential seizures
    • Peripheral Nervous System: Paresthesias, muscle cramps, tetany (similar to hypocalcemia effects)
    • Cardiovascular: Aggravation of arrhythmias, particularly in COPD patients
  • Electrolyte Imbalances
    • Potassium (K⁺): Hypokalemia, especially in cases involving secondary hyperaldosteronism or diuretic use.
    • Chloride (Cl⁻): Hypochloremia, frequently accompanying alkalosis, especially in cases of vomiting or diuretic use.
    • Calcium (Ca²⁺): Symptoms may mimic hypocalcemia despite normal levels.

Incorrect Options:

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) (Option A) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by high blood sugar levels, increased body ketone concentration, and metabolic acidosis.

Septic shock (Option C) can lead to multiple organ dysfunction and a state of metabolic acidosis. The pH of 7.52 in the ABG report suggests alkalosis rather than acidosis, so septic shock is unlikely to be the cause.

Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) (Option D) is a condition characterized by a defect in the kidneys’ ability to excrete acid, leading to a buildup of acid in the body. Since the ABG report shows alkalosis with a pH of 7.52, RTA is not the likely cause.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with laboured breathing. ECG shows tall, tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) pH-7.14, pCO2-20 mmHg, HCO3- 5 mEq/L

Explanation:

  • The low pH and HCO3 levels in the blood show metabolic acidosis.

Metabolic acidosis

Definition
  • Primary decrease in HCO3⁻ or increase in H⁺ ions
  • Characterized by ↓ pH and ↓ HCO3⁻
  • Compensatory mechanism: ↓ PaCO2 through hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing)

Types

High anion gap (AG > 12 mEq/L)

Normal anion gap (AG 6-12 mEq/L)

Causes

(Mnemonic: MUDPILES)

  • M: Methanol
  • U: Uremia (Renal failure)
  • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • P: Paraldehyde, Phenformin, Propylene glycol
  • I: Iron tablets, Isoniazid
  • L: Lactic acidosis
  • E: Ethylene glycol
  • S: Salicylates (late phase)

(Mnemonic: HARD UP)

  • H: Hyperalimentation (TPN)
  • A: Acetazolamide
  • R: Renal Tubular Acidosis
  • D: Diarrhea
  • U: Ureteral diversion
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • GIT fistulas

Clinical Features

General Features:

  • Lethargy
  • Confusion
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Deep, rapid breathing (Kussmaul)

Specific Features:

  • DKA: Fruity breath, polyuria, polydipsia
  • Uremia: Itching, volume overload
  • Lactic acidosis: Shock, hypotension
  • Toxic ingestion: Visual disturbances (methanol), oxalate crystals (ethylene glycol)

Incorrect Options:

pH-7.14, pCO2-20 mmHg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L (Option B): Although the pH and pCO₂ suggest acidemia with respiratory compensation, the high HCO₃⁻ (34 mEq/L) is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis. A high bicarbonate would be seen in metabolic alkalosis, which does not fit this clinical picture.

pH-7.54, HCO3- 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 34 mmHg (Option C): This option shows a high pH (7.54), indicating alkalosis. The pCO₂ is slightly low, suggesting respiratory alkalosis, while the HCO₃⁻ is near normal. This acid-base picture does not match the metabolic acidosis expected in a dialysis patient with hyperkalemia.

pH-7.4, HCO3- 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mmHg (Option D): This combination of normal pH, normal pCO2, and normal HCO3- does not indicate any significant acid-base imbalance. Therefore, this option is less likely to be the correct acid-base imbalance in this case.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with a fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest x-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Streptococcus pneumonia

Explanation:

  • The given scenario is of pneumonia in an AIDS-infected child. The most common organism causing fever, and productive cough, with given examination findings, is Streptococcus pneumonia.

Pneumonia Etiology and Common Pathogens

  • Main Pathogens: Bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa.
    • Typical Bacteria: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA).
    • Atypical Bacteria: Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, Legionella species
    • Viruses: Influenza, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), coronaviruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2).

Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

Atypical Pneumonia

Outpatients

Hospitalised Patients

Includes M.pneumoniae C.pneumoniae, and Legionella species.

Common causes:

S.pneumoniae, M.pneumoniae

H. influenzae, C.pneumoniae, Respiratory viruses (influenza, RSV).

Non-ICU

ICU Patients

Similar pathogens to outpatients, plus Legionella species.

Pathogens include S.pneumoniae, S. aureus (including MRSA), Legionella species, gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae.

Specific Pathogens in Certain Conditions:

Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA):
  • It can cause CAP, often complicating influenza infections.
  • Community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) has emerged as a significant cause of necrotizing pneumonia.

Pneumococcal Pneumonia:
  • Higher risk in elderly patients, and those with comorbidities like dementia, heart failure, cerebrovascular disease, alcoholism, smoking, COPD, and HIV infection.

CA-MRSA Pneumonia:
  • More likely in patients with prior skin infections or following viral illnesses.

Enterobacteriaceae:
  • Common in patients recently hospitalized, those treated with antibiotics, or those with comorbidities like alcoholism, heart failure, or renal failure.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
  • Found in patients with severe structural lung diseases such as bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, or advanced COPD.

Legionella Infection:
  • Associated with risk factors like diabetes, hematologic malignancies, cancer, severe renal disease, HIV, smoking, male gender, and recent travel (air conditioners, showers, hotels, cruise ships). It is an important cause of atypical pneumonia.

Incorrect Options:

Pneumocystis jirovecii (Option A) pneumonia (PJP) is a common opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS. However, it typically presents with non-productive cough, shortness of breath, and bilateral diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option C) is another bacterium that can cause pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals, including those with AIDS. It is known for causing severe infections, including necrotizing pneumonia, but not the most common cause.

Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Option D) is an atypical bacterium that can cause pneumonia, particularly in children and young adults. It often presents with a milder respiratory illness, including a persistent cough, headache, sore throat, and patchy infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation in the chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and is admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Non-invasive PPV should be given
Explanation: The initial management for acute exacerbation of COPD is non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (PPV), as it helps reduce the work of breathing and improves gas exchange, leading to better outcomes, including reduced hospital duration and improved overall survival outcomes.

Management of Acute Exacerbation of COPD:

  • Initial Management and Assessment:
    • Home management: Increased bronchodilator therapy, short course of oral glucocorticoids, and possibly antibiotics.
    • Hospital referral indicators:
      • Cyanosis
      • Peripheral oedema
      • Altered consciousness
    • Comprehensive assessment upon admission:
      • Level of consciousness (response to commands, ability to cough)
      • Signs of CO2 retention (warm peripheries, bounding pulse, flapping tremor)
      • Airway obstruction assessment (wheeze, prolonged expiration)
      • Signs of cor pulmonale (peripheral oedema, raised JVP)
      • Background functional status and quality of life
      • Precipitating causes (e.g., infection, environmental factors)

 

Investigations:

Investigation

Purpose/Findings

Arterial blood gases

Assess severity of hypoxaemia, hypercapnia, acidaemia; guide oxygen therapy and ventilation.

Chest X-ray

Identify complications such as pneumonia, pneumothorax, or pleural effusion.

Management Strategies:

Management

Details

Oxygen Therapy
  • Administer controlled oxygen at 24% or 28% to maintain PaO2 > 8 kPa (60 mmHg) or SaO2 > 90%.
  • Regular arterial blood gas monitoring to adjust therapy.

Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV)
  • Safe for mild to moderate respiratory acidosis; helps reduce intubation need and mortality.
  • Not suitable for patients unable to protect their airway.

Bronchodilators
  • Use nebulised short-acting β2-agonists (e.g., salbutamol, terbutaline) with anticholinergics (e.g., ipratropium).
  • If oxygen sensitivity is a concern, use compressed air for nebulisation.

Glucocorticoids
  • Administer oral prednisolone (30 mg for 10 days) to reduce symptoms and improve lung function.Reduces frequency and severity of exacerbations.
  • Consider osteoporosis prophylaxis for repeated courses.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Indicated for increased sputum purulence, volume, or breathlessness.
  • Use simple regimens (aminopenicillin, tetracycline, macrolide); co-amoxiclav in areas with β-lactamase organisms.

Mechanical Ventilation (Option B)
  • Consider if there is a reversible cause, no prior respiratory failure, or if NIV has failed/contraindicated.
  • Decisions should involve the patient, family, and GP.

Additional Therapy
  • Diuretics for peripheral oedema.
  • Limited evidence for intravenous aminophylline; consider arrhythmia risk.
  • Doxapram may be used short-term for low respiratory rates.
  • Discharge and Follow-Up:
    • Discharge criteria:
      • Clinically stable on maintenance medication.
      • Off nebulised therapy for at least 24 hours.
      • PEF reaches 75% of predicted or personal best.
    • Post-exacerbation follow-up:
      • Identify and avoid trigger factors.
      • Provide asthma education and a written self-management plan.

 

IV corticosteroids should be administered (Option C): Systemic corticosteroids are helpful in treating acute COPD exacerbations by reducing airway inflammation and improving lung function over time, but their effects are not immediate. Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV), on the other hand, provides immediate respiratory support, reducing the work of breathing and stabilizing the patient's condition, making it the priority in the initial management.

Permissive hypercapnia is allowed (Option D): Permissive hypercapnia involves allowing elevated carbon dioxide levels to avoid lung injury from over-ventilation, but this is not an approach used in the initial management of acute COPD exacerbations. The goal during the acute phase is to normalize blood gases and relieve respiratory distress, which is best achieved with NIPPV. Permissive hypercapnia is typically considered only after NIPPV fails and invasive positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) is required.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - 4

  • The clinical scenario of a patient with dyspnea, bilateral pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, elevated jugular venous pulse (JVP), and a palpable liver strongly suggests right ventricular (RV) failure. Chronic smoking is a key risk factor for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which can lead to cor pulmonale, a condition where the right ventricle fails due to prolonged lung disease. Therefore, the abnormality lies in the right ventricle, as indicated in option D.

Cor Pulmonale:

  • Alteration in the structure and function of the right ventricle (RV) caused by a primary respiratory disorder leading to pulmonary hypertension.
  • Etiology:
    • Lung Diseases: COPD, interstitial lung disease, scleroderma, cystic fibrosis, obesity hypoventilation syndrome.
    • Vascular Disorders: Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.
    • Upper Airway: Obstructive sleep apnea.
    • Chest Wall Disorders: Kyphoscoliosis.
    • Massive Pulmonary Embolism: Leading cause of acute cor pulmonale, may mimic myocardial infarction with elevated troponins and chest pain.
    • COPD: Most common cause of chronic cor pulmonale.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Chronic hypoxemia leads to pulmonary vasoconstriction and smooth muscle proliferation in small pulmonary arteries.
    • Increased pulmonary vascular resistance causes right ventricular enlargement (thickening, dilation).
  • Symptoms:
    • Dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, lethargy, exertional syncope, chest pain, abdominal edema, and lower extremity edema.
    • Clinical signs appear later, after pulmonary hypertension develops
  • Physical Findings:
    • Jugular Venous Distension: Prominent jugular V wave (tricuspid regurgitation).
    • Peripheral Edema: Non-specific but common in right heart failure.
    • Cardiovascular: Parasternal lift, loud S2, narrow S2 splitting, holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation, right-sided S4 heart sound.
    • Abdomen: Hepatomegaly, ascites.
  • Investigations:
    • Chest Radiograph: Pulmonary artery enlargement, right ventricular cardiomegaly.
    • ECG: Right ventricular hypertrophy/enlargement.
    • Chest CT Angiography: Rules out pulmonary embolism, pulmonary artery diameter >29 mm.
  • Management:
    • Oxygen Therapy: Improves oxygenation, reduces pulmonary vasoconstriction, enhances cardiac output.
    • Diuretics: Reduces RV filling volume in chronic cor pulmonale.

questions.text:
Acid-base imbalance is suspected in a patient. Which of the following would you use to determine it?


	Arterial pH
	Venous pH
	Venous pO2
	Venous pCO2
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 1,2

  • Acid-base imbalance can be determined using arterial and venous pH.
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is the gold standard for assessing acid-base imbalance; however, venous blood gas (VBG) analysis correlates well with ABG and is a safer, less invasive alternative.
  • The mean pH difference between ABG and VBG is minimal (ABG pH is higher by 0.03), making venous pH values acceptable for clinical use.

Venous pO2 (Option 3): Venous and arterial pO2 values are not comparable because arterial pO2 is typically 36.9 mmHg higher than venous pO₂, with significant variability.

Venous pCO2 (Option 4): Venous and arterial pCO2 are not directly comparable as the mean difference between them is approximately 4.8 mmHg, which limits its reliability in assessing acid-base imbalance.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a negative vasoreactive test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B  - Ambrisentan

  • In patients with class II (low risk) pulmonary hypertension and a negative vasoreactive test, the next step in management is the use of ambrisentan, an endothelin receptor antagonist.

Vasoreactivity Testing in PAH:

  • Indication: Vasoreactivity testing is primarily reserved for patients with idiopathic or hereditary PAH.
  • Preferred Vasodilators: Short-acting vasodilators such as inhaled nitric oxide (NO) or inhaled epoprostenol are preferred for the test.
  • Positive Response: A decrease in mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP) by ≥10 mmHg to an absolute level of ≤40 mmHg without a decrease in cardiac output (CO) is considered a positive vasoreactivity response.
  • Treatment for Responders:
    • Patients with a positive vasoreactivity response are considered for long-term treatment with calcium channel blockers (nifedipine, diltiazem or amlodipine). (Option C)
  • Negative Vasoreactivity: Treatment approach depends on clinical risk.
    • Low- or Intermediate-Risk Patients (class II, III): Initial treatment includes combination oral therapy, typically involving an endothelin receptor antagonist (ambrisentan, sitaxsentan or bosentan) and a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor (sildenafil or tadalafil).
    • High-Risk Patients (Class IV): Patients with advanced heart failure or syncope are treated with combination drug therapy, which includes intravenous prostacyclin therapy (epoprostenol, treprostinil or iloprost). (Option A & D)

Classification of PAH:

  • Group 1: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)
  • Group 2: Pulmonary hypertension due to left heart disease
  • Group 3: Pulmonary hypertension due to lung disease or hypoxia
  • Group 4: Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension
  • Group 5: Pulmonary hypertension due to unclear and/multifactorial mechanisms

questions.text:
During the discharge of a COVID patient who was treated with steroids and remdesivir, which of the following will you inform him about?


	Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge
	Watch for the persistence of Anosmia
	Watch for headache and nasal discharge
	Monitor glucose levels
	Watch for Sinusitis like symptoms
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 3, 4 and 5

  • Patients treated with steroids and remdesivir for COVID-19 require careful monitoring during discharge. It is crucial to monitor glucose levels (4) because steroids can cause hyperglycemia. Additionally, watching for sinusitis-like symptoms (5), including headache and nasal discharge (3), is important due to the increased incidence of mucormycosis in COVID-19 patients.

Revised Discharge Policy for COVID-19:

  • Mild Cases of COVID-19:
    • Discharge criteria:
      • At least 7 days have passed since testing positive.
      • No fever for 3 successive days.
    • No testing is required prior to discharge.
  • Moderate Cases Admitted to Dedicated COVID Health Centre
    • Patients with resolved signs/symptoms and saturation >93% for 3 successive days:
      • Discharge after resolution of symptoms and maintaining saturation above 93% for 3 successive days (without oxygen support).
      • Stable comorbidities, if any, are required.
      • No testing is required prior to discharge.
    • Patients on oxygen with unresolved signs/symptoms and ongoing oxygen therapy demand:
      • Discharge only after the following criteria are met:
        • Resolution of clinical symptoms.
        • Ability to maintain prescribed oxygen saturation for 3 successive days without oxygen support.
        • Stable comorbidities, if any.
  • Severe Cases, Including Immunocompromised Patients (HIV, transplant recipients, malignancy, etc.)
    • Discharge will be based on clinical recovery.
    • The decision is at the discretion of the treating medical officer.

Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge (Option 1): This is not recommended under the updated COVID-19 discharge criteria.

Watch for persistence of anosmia (Option 2): Anosmia is a common post-COVID symptom that may persist for weeks to months in recovered patients. It is not considered a dangerous sign and does not require active monitoring during the discharge period.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypoventilation

Explanation: Hypoventilation causes hypoxemia by reducing both alveolar and arterial oxygen levels equally, resulting in a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient.

 

Alveolar-Arterial Oxygen Gradient (A-a Gradient):

  • The A-a gradient measures the difference between the oxygen concentration in the alveoli (PAO2) and the oxygen concentration in the arterial system (PaO2).
  • Helps narrow the differential diagnosis for hypoxemia.
  • A-a Gradient Formula:
    A-a Gradient = PAO2 – PaO2
    (PAO2 = Alveolar oxygen tension, PaO2 = Arterial oxygen tension).
  • Hypoventilation and A-a Gradient:
  • Hypoventilation occurs when there is inadequate ventilation of the lungs, leading to decreased oxygen levels in the arterial system.
  • Causes of Hypoventilation:
    • CNS depression.
    • Neuromuscular diseases (e.g., myasthenia gravis).
    • Poor chest elasticity (e.g., kyphoscoliosis).
    • Vertebral fractures and other factors.
  • Hypoventilation affects both arterial oxygen tension (PaO₂) and alveolar oxygen tension (AₐO₂), resulting in decreased oxygen levels in both the respiratory and circulatory systems.
  • The A-a gradient (the difference between alveolar and arterial oxygen tensions) remains normal in hypoventilation because both PaO₂ and AₐO₂ decrease in proportion.

 

Right to left shunt (Option A): In a right-to-left shunt, oxygenated blood bypasses the alveoli, mixing with deoxygenated blood and causing hypoxemia. This leads to an increased A-a gradient, as diffusion between capillaries and alveoli remains unaffected, but the lack of oxygenation of the shunted blood worsens the oxygenation process.

Ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch (Option B) leads to a disparity between ventilation and perfusion in the lungs, resulting in an increased A-a gradient. This is because some areas of the lung are either under-ventilated or under-perfused, impairing the gas exchange process and increasing the gradient.

Alveolar membrane damage (Option D), seen in conditions like ARDS or pulmonary fibrosis, impairs the diffusion of oxygen across the alveolar-capillary barrier. This causes an increased A-a gradient as oxygen fails to transfer efficiently from the alveoli into the bloodstream, leading to hypoxemia.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever for the past 4 days and sudden onset of breathlessness was admitted to ICU as he was deteriorating. He was unresponsive to the incremental flow rate of oxygen and his oxygen saturation was progressively decreasing. A chest x-ray was ordered and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) ARDS

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis of this patient is Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).
  • ARDS is a severe lung condition characterized by widespread inflammation and damage to the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs. It can be triggered by various factors, including infection, sepsis, trauma, or inhalation injury. The key features of ARDS include acute onset of severe hypoxemia (low oxygen levels) that is refractory to supplemental oxygen, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on imaging (such as the chest X-ray), and impaired lung compliance.

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS):

  • ARDS is a diffuse neutrophilic alveolitis caused by infective & non-infective triggers.

Berlin definition of ARDS:

  • Onset within 1 week of a known clinical insult, or new or worsening respiratory symptoms
  • Bilateral opacities on chest X-ray, not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse or nodules
  • Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload.
  • Objective assessment (e.g. by echocardiography) must exclude hydrostatic oedema if no risk factor is present Impaired oxygenation

Pathophysiology:

  • Activated neutrophils & macrophages → capillary permeability ↑ → alveolar damage
  • Protein-rich exudate accumulation → hyaline membrane formation
  • Cytokine & chemokine release → inflammatory cell recruitment
  • Surfactant loss → alveolar collapse & ↓ lung compliance
  • Hypoxaemia & hypercapnia due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch

ARDS Severity (PaO2/FiO2 Ratio in kPa):

  • Mild: 40–26.6 kPa (300–200 mmHg)
  • Moderate: 26.6–13.3 kPa (200–100 mmHg)
  • Severe: ≤ 13.3 kPa (≤ 100 mmHg)
    (Measured on ≥5 cmH₂O PEEP or CPAP)

(CPAP = continuous positive airway pressure; PEEP = positive end-expiratory pressure)

Management:

  • Supportive care: Lung-protective mechanical ventilation, negative fluid balance, and treat underlying cause
  • Severe ARDS: Requires prone positioning, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)

 

Atelectasis (Option A) refers to the collapse or incomplete expansion of lung tissue. It can result from blockage of the airways, compression of the lung, or surfactant deficiency. While atelectasis can cause localized or segmental lung collapse, it typically does not lead to widespread bilateral infiltrates and severe hypoxemia.

Pulmonary fibrosis (Option C) typically presents with a gradual onset of symptoms, such as shortness of breath and cough, and the chest X-ray findings would show a reticular or honeycomb pattern.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with the following arterial blood gas (ABG) results: pH 7.55, PaCO2 40 mmHg, HCO3- 32 mEq/L. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metabolic alkalosis

Explanation:

  • The elevated pH (>7.45) and increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) (32 mEq/L), indicates a primary metabolic alkalosis.

Metabolic Alkalosis

  • Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an increase in arterial pH, elevated serum bicarbonate [HCO3−], and increased PaCO2​ due to compensatory hypoventilation.
  • Often presents with hypochloremia and hypokalemia.
  • Occurs as a mixed disorder with respiratory or metabolic acidosis or alkalosis.
  • Causes
    • Exogenous Bicarbonate Loads
      • Acute alkali administration
      • Milk-alkali syndrome
    • Effective ECFV Contraction (Normotension, K+ Deficiency, Secondary Hyperreninemic Hyperaldosteronism)
      • Gastrointestinal Origin: Vomiting, gastric aspiration, congenital chloridorrhea, gastrocystoplasty, villous adenoma
      • Renal Origin: Diuretic use (thiazides, loop diuretics), posthypercapnic state, hypercalcemia/hypoparathyroidism, recovery from acidosis, non-resorbable anions (e.g., penicillin), Mg²⁺ deficiency, K⁺ depletion, Bartter's syndrome, Gitelman's syndrome
    • ECFV Expansion, Hypertension, K+ Deficiency, and Mineralocorticoid Excess
      • High Renin: Renal artery stenosis, accelerated hypertension, renin-secreting tumor, estrogen therapy
      • Low Renin: Primary aldosteronism (adenoma, hyperplasia, carcinoma), adrenal enzyme defects (11β-hydroxylase, 17α-hydroxylase deficiency), Cushing’s syndrome, substances like licorice, carbenoxolone
    • Genetic Sodium Channel Mutation (Liddle's Syndrome)
    • Gain-of-function mutation in the distal convoluted tubule, causing ECFV expansion, hypertension, K⁺ deficiency, and hypo-reninemic-hypoaldosteronism
  • Clinical Features
    • Neurological: Mental confusion, obtundation, potential seizures
    • Peripheral Nervous System: Paresthesias, muscle cramps, tetany (similar to hypocalcemia effects)
    • Cardiovascular: Aggravation of arrhythmias, particularly in COPD patients
  • Electrolyte Imbalances
    • Potassium (K⁺): Hypokalemia, especially in cases involving secondary hyperaldosteronism or diuretic use.
    • Chloride (Cl⁻): Hypochloremia, frequently accompanying alkalosis, especially in cases of vomiting or diuretic use.
    • Calcium (Ca²⁺): Symptoms may mimic hypocalcemia despite normal levels.

 

Metabolic acidosis (Option A) would show a low pH and low bicarbonate levels.

Respiratory acidosis (Option C) is characterized by a low pH and elevated PaCO₂

Respiratory alkalosis (Option D) would show a high pH with low PaCO₂.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings from a pleural fluid aspirate will suggest an exudative pleural effusion?


	Normal values
	Total S. Protein: 6-8 gm%
	S.LDH: 140-280 IU
	S. glucose: 140-200

choices.text: Pleural: Serum protein ratio > 0.5, pleural: Serum LDH ratio > 0.6 or pleural LDH > ⅔ of serum LDH
Pleural fluid protein = 4.5 gm% and glucose = 30 mg%
Pleural fluid LDH = 90IU and glucose = 30 mg%
Pleural fluid protein = 3.5gm% and glucose = 90 mg%

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pleural: Serum protein ratio > 0.5, pleural: Serum LDH ratio > 0.6 or pleural LDH > 2/3

Explanation:

To classify the effusion as transudative or exudative, we apply Light's criteria:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum LDH

Investigation of pleural fluid

Radiological investigation

X-ray:

  • 200 mL of fluid is needed for detection on the posteroanterior (PA) view.
  • 50 mL of fluid may lead to blunting of the costophrenic angle on the lateral view.
  • A homogeneous opacity with obliteration of the costophrenic angle is typical.
  • This appearance is marked by a curved upper border, known as the Ellis S-shaped curve.
  • Obliteration of cardiophrenic angle.

Ultrasound: More effective than X-ray in detecting fluid presence, showing a clear hypoechoic space indicative of transudate and moving densities suggesting exudate.

Pleural fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Additional Tests for Exudative Effusions
  • Appearance description
  • Glucose level, If Glucose <60 mg/dL Consider:
    • Malignancy
    • Bacterial infections (empyema)
    • Rheumatoid pleuritis
  • Differential cell count
  • Microbiologic studies
  • Cytology

Standard Peculiarities

  • Heart Failure: NT-proBNP level > 1500 pg/mL indicates effusion due to congestive heart failure
  • Parapneumonic Effusion: Key criteria include:
    • Loculated pleural fluid
    • Pleural fluid pH < 7.20
    • Pleural fluid glucose < 3.3 mmol/L (< 60 mg/dL) ( Option B, C)
    • Positive Gram stain or culture results
    • Presence of visible pus
  • Tuberculous Pleuritis: Diagnosis confirmed by high TB markers in pleural fluid (adenosine deaminase > 40 IU/L or interferon γ > 140 pg/mL)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Since the criteria suggest an exudate, which is often associated with other conditions like malignancy or infection rather than just congestive heart failure (Option D).

questions.text: Which one of the following is a direct cause of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)?

choices.text: Fat embolism syndrome following femur shaft fracture

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs that primarily affects the alveoli.
  • Severe pneumonia can cause respiratory distress which directly leads to ARDS.
  • Pneumonia is considered a parenchymal lung disease.
  • Both Pneumonia > Sepsis are the leading causes of ARDS

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fat embolism syndrome following femur shaft fracture: Fat embolism syndrome occurs when fat globules are released into the bloodstream, typically following long bone fractures. These fat globules can obstruct blood vessels in the lungs, leading to inflammation and lung injury. Fat embolism syndrome can cause ARDS at the blood-lung interface.

Option C - Sepsis: Sepsis is a systemic inflammatory response to infection that can lead to organ dysfunction. In severe cases, sepsis can cause ARDS, as the inflammatory response affects the blood-lung interface and results in lung injury.

Option D - Transfusion-related lung injury: Transfusion-related lung injury (TRALI) occurs when donor antibodies or other components in blood products trigger an immune response, leading to lung injury. TRALI can cause ARDS at the blood-lung interface.

questions.text: Old man underwent joint replacement surgery 3 days ago. Today he develops SOB with chest pain. O/E : pulse 100/min, BP 100/70 mm Hg, RR28/min and sp02: 85% room air. D-dimer is elevated. Which is the next best test
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) CTPA

Explanation: This patient has acute-onset dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxia, and elevated D-dimer 3 days post–orthopedic surgery, which is highly suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE).

  • In a hemodynamically stable patient with high pretest probability (post-surgery, classic symptoms), the next best test is CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA), the gold standard for diagnosis as it directly visualizes thrombi in pulmonary arteries.

 

Pulmonary Embolism - Clinical Features and Vitals Examination

Clinical Features

Vital Signs

  • Unexplained dyspnea
  • Pleuritic chest pain
  • Hemoptysis
  • Syncope
  • Apprehension.
  • Crushing central chest pain
  • Calf cramps

Severe Pulmonary Embolism:

  • Sudden collapse of the patient.
  • Severe hypotension
  • Cyanosis
  • Heart Rate: ↑
  • Respiratory Rate: ↑
  • Blood Pressure: ↓
  • Oxygen Saturation: ↓ (hypoxemia)
  • Temperature: ↑ (low-grade fever)

 

 

Pulmonary embolism (PE)

Causes

Pathophysiology

Most PE originates from deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the lower limbs.

Other rare causes include:

  • Septic emboli (from endocarditis affecting the tricuspid or pulmonary valves).
  • Fat emboli (after fractures of long bones, e.g., femur).
  • Tumour emboli (e.g., choriocarcinoma).
  • Air emboli (In ENT and neurosurgeries commonly)
  • Amniotic fluid emboli (after delivery).

 

PE occurs when a blood clot (thrombus) travels to the lungs, blocking blood flow in the pulmonary artery.

Impaired Gas Exchange:

  • Increased anatomic and physiologic dead space due to decreased gas exchange.
  • Hypoxemia and increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient result from poor ventilation-perfusion matching.

Increased Pulmonary Vascular Resistance:

  • Vascular obstruction by the clot and release of vasoconstricting agents like serotonin.
  • Causes ventilation-perfusion mismatch even in areas away from the embolus.

Pulmonary Hypertension: Blockage of the pulmonary artery increases pressure, leading to strain on the right heart.

Right Ventricular (RV) Dysfunction:

  • RV dilatation and failure due to increased afterload.
  • RV microinfarction can occur with large PE, leading to elevated serum troponin and brain natriuretic peptide.

V/Q scan (Option A): Used if CTPA is contraindicated (e.g., contrast allergy, severe renal failure), but here CTPA is preferred.

ECG (Option B): May show nonspecific changes (e.g., sinus tachycardia, S1Q3T3), but not diagnostic for PE.

CXR (Option C): Usually normal or nonspecific (e.g., atelectasis, pleural effusion) and cannot confirm PE.

questions.text: A patient with COVID-19 pneumonia is admitted with severe respiratory distress and their PaO₂/FiO₂ is < 100. What is the most appropriate ventilatory strategy in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High PEEP, low tidal volume

Explanation: The clinical presentation points towards ARDS

  • (PaO₂/FiO₂ < 100 mmHg with PEEP ≥ 5 cm H₂O).

ARDS management in COVID-19 follows lung-protective ventilation:

  • Low tidal volume: Prevent volutrauma.
  • Higher PEEP: Improves alveolar recruitment and oxygenation in severe hypoxemia.

Low PEEP, high tidal volume (Option A): Causes alveolar overdistension and barotrauma; worsens mortality.

Low tidal volume, low PEEP (Option C): Tidal volume is correct, but low PEEP is inadequate for severe ARDS and leads to derecruitment.

High tidal volume, high PEEP (Option D): High PEEP helps oxygenation, but high tidal volumes increase risk of ventilator-induced lung injury.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive shortness of breath for the last 6 months, accompanied by dry cough. Auscultation reveals bilateral basal end-inspiratory crepitations. There is no history of fever, joint pain, or occupational exposure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – IPF:

Explanation:

  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic, progressive fibrosing interstitial lung disease of unknown cause, typically seen in older adults.
  • The classic presentation includes gradually worsening exertional dyspnoea and nonproductive cough over months.
  • On auscultation, bilateral basal end-inspiratory “Velcro” crackles are characteristic.
  • Absence of fever, joint symptoms, or occupational dust/fume exposure supports an idiopathic diagnosis rather than secondary interstitial lung disease.

Incorrect Options:

Cor-pulmonale (Option A): Refers to right ventricular hypertrophy and failure secondary to chronic lung disease or pulmonary hypertension; it is a consequence, not the primary cause, of the lung findings here.

Sarcoidosis (Option B): Usually presents with systemic features, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and may involve skin or eyes; less likely here due to absence of extrapulmonary signs and chronicity pattern.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (Option D): Generally linked to a clear history of antigen exposure (birds, mold, farming) and has a more acute/subacute onset; no such history is present in this case.

questions.text: A patient presents with SOB and fatigue. CXR was done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Asbestosis

Explanation:

  • Asbestosis is an interstitial lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers, often in occupations such as shipbuilding, construction, or insulation work.
  • The hallmark radiologic finding is calcified pleural plaques, especially along the parietal pleura and diaphragm (“peripheral pleural calcification”), along with lower lobe interstitial fibrosis.
  • Patients present with progressive dyspnea and restrictive lung disease on PFTs.

Incorrect Options:

TB (Option A): More commonly involves apical regions, with cavitation and infiltrates; pleural calcifications are uncommon.

Silicosis (Option C): Typically shows upper lobe nodules and “eggshell” hilar node calcification.

Byssinosis (Option D): Cotton dust–related disease, usually without pleural calcification.

questions.text: A patient is in ICU and there is a failed attempt of subclavian catheterization. Shortly after, BP drops and the pulse rises. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumothorax

Explanation:
 

  • Subclavian vein catheterization carries a significant risk of pleural injury, which can cause pneumothorax.
  • Air entry into the pleural space leads to reduced venous return, causing hypotension and reflex tachycardia.
  • In the ICU setting, this can rapidly progress to tension pneumothorax, which is life-threatening and requires urgent decompression.
  • Typical signs: sudden drop in BP, tachycardia, respiratory distress, unilateral decreased breath sounds, hyperresonance on percussion.

Incorrect Options:

Displacement of ET (Option B): Would cause hypoxia and respiratory distress, but is not directly related to subclavian line attempt.

Air embolism (Option C): Can occur during line placement, but presents with sudden cardiovascular collapse and possibly a "mill wheel" murmur; pneumothorax is more common post failed subclavian attempt.

Dislodgement of ET (Option D): Would cause airway compromise but unrelated to catheterization unless ET manipulation occurred.

questions.text: On examination, a person has distended neck veins, absent breath sounds, hyperresonance, and a shift of the trachea. What is the management?

choices.text: Bedside CXR in casualty followed by chest tube insertion

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Wide bore needle in 2nd ICS:

Explanation:

  • This is tension pneumothorax – caused by air trapping in the pleural space under pressure.
  • Key signs:
    • Respiratory distress
    • Hyperresonance (air in pleural space)
    • Absent breath sounds (no lung expansion)
    • Distended neck veins (↑ intrathoracic pressure → ↓ venous return)
    • Tracheal shift away from the affected side (mass effect)
  • In tension pneumothorax, waiting for imaging can be fatal.
  • Immediate needle decompression is done in the 2nd intercostal space, midclavicular line using a wide-bore cannula, followed by chest tube insertion.

Tension Pneumothorax:

  • Pathophysiology: Air enters the pleural space during inspiration but cannot exit (one-way valve mechanism). This increases intrapleural pressure → lung collapse → mediastinal shift → compression of heart and opposite lung → obstructive shock.
  • Causes: trauma, mechanical ventilation, rib fractures, ruptured bleb.
  • Emergency Management:
    • Needle decompression (life-saving) – 2nd ICS MCL or 4th/5th ICS anterior axillary line.
    • Chest tube thoracostomy in the 4th/5th ICS mid-axillary line after decompression.

Incorrect Options:

Bedside CXR in casualty followed by chest tube insertion (Option A) – Wrong because waiting for imaging delays life-saving decompression.

Pericardiocentesis (Option C) – For cardiac tamponade, not pneumothorax.

Pleurodesis with doxycycline (Option D) – For recurrent pneumothorax, not for acute life-threatening tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with complaints of dyspnea. Pulmonary function tests reveal an FEV1/FVC ratio of 65% and an RV/TLC ratio of 141%. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology?

choices.text: Air trapping with hyperinflation of lungs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Air trapping with hyperinflation of lungs

Explanation:

  • Given the history of chronic smoking, symptoms of dyspnea and Obstructive pattern on PFTs, this presentation is most consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), especially emphysema, which is characterized by destruction of alveolar walls, air trapping, and lung hyperinflation.
  • Smoking leads to inflammation and destruction of elastic fibers in the lungs, resulting in reduced airway recoil, premature airway closure, and gas trapping, which are hallmarks of emphysema.

Pathogenesis of COPD

Risk Factors

  • Cigarette Smoking: Primary risk, correlates with amount and duration.
  • Environmental Factors:
    • Indoor air pollution (e.g., biomass fuel use in confined spaces).
    • Occupational exposures (e.g., coal dust, silica, cadmium).
  • Developmental Factors:
    • Low birth weight and impaired lung growth from infections or maternal smoking.
  • Infections:
    • Recurrent infections accelerate lung decline.
    • Persistent adenovirus may alter inflammatory responses, leading to damage.
  • Genetic Factors:
    • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. (Option B ruled out)
    • Airway hyper-reactivity.

Components of COPD

Pulmonary Components

Description

Mucus hypersecretion

Enlargement of mucus glands and goblet cells → chronic bronchitis (cough + sputum for ≥3 months/year).

Emphysema

Alveolar destruction by proteases and oxidants → permanent enlargement of distal airspaces.

Airflow Limitation

Loss of elastic tissue + inflammation → premature airway closure, gas trapping, and hyperinflation.

This is the primary mechanism for the airflow limitation.

Pulmonary vascular remodeling

Structural changes in pulmonary vessels.eventually causing PAH.

 

Systemic Components

Description

Weight Loss

Altered fat metabolism.

Skeletal Muscle Dysfunction

Muscle impairment reduces physical capacity.

Peripheral Edema

Impaired kidney function → salt and water retention.

Osteoporosis

Decreased bone density.

Increased Inflammatory Markers

Elevated systemic inflammation contributes to complications.

Incorrect Options:

Decreased lung compliance (Option B): Seen in restrictive lung diseases (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis). COPD/emphysema features increased, not decreased, compliance due to alveolar wall destruction.

Restrictive lung disease (Option C): Would show normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio and decreased lung volumes, not increased RV/TLC.

questions.text: The patient being discussed has come in for medical evaluation following an injury to the chest. During the examination, the presence of crepitus is detected. Based on these findings, what is the likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subcutaneous emphysema:

  • Crepitus refers to the sensation of crackling or crunching felt under the skin. It occurs when air or gas escapes from the damaged respiratory or gastrointestinal tract and dissects through the subcutaneous tissues. The presence of crepitus is a characteristic finding in subcutaneous emphysema.
  • The description of the image-based question mentioning the face of the man showing edema is not directly related to the diagnosis of subcutaneous emphysema. Edema refers to the swelling caused by an accumulation of fluid in the tissues, and it can have various causes. However, it is not a specific feature of subcutaneous emphysema.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gas gangrene: Gas gangrene is a severe and potentially life-threatening infection caused by certain bacteria, such as Clostridium species. It is characterized by the rapid spread of infection, tissue destruction, and gas production within the affected tissues. Gas gangrene is not directly related to chest trauma or the presence of crepitus, so it is an incorrect option in this case.

Option C - Acute tubular necrosis: Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is a type of kidney injury that can occur due to various causes, such as ischemia, toxins, or infections. It involves damage to the renal tubules, leading to impaired kidney function. ATN is not directly related to chest trauma or the presence of crepitus, so it is an incorrect option in this scenario.

Option D - Hyperbaric decompression sickness: Hyperbaric decompression sickness, commonly known as "the bends," is a condition that can occur in scuba divers when they ascend too quickly, leading to the formation of gas bubbles in the bloodstream. It primarily affects divers and is not directly related to chest trauma or the presence of crepitus. Therefore, it is an incorrect option in this context.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. The absolute eosinophil count is >5000/µL. Chest x-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

Explanation:

  • The nocturnal cough, fever, breathlessness, and wheezing with eosinophilia of >5000/µL and miliary pattern in chest X-ray all point to the diagnosis of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE)

  • TPE is a pulmonary hyperreactive condition triggered by trapped microfilariae in lung tissue, leading to symptoms like nocturnal cough, dyspnea, and wheezing.

Pathophysiology:

  • Eosinophils are key in the pathogenesis, triggered by microfilariae released from the lymphatic system that become trapped in pulmonary microcirculation.
  • Eosinophils degranulate, releasing proteins to clear microfilariae and cause lung damage.
  • IL-4 promotes airway hyperactivity, while IFN-gamma suppresses it.
  • An overactive TH2 response increases IL-4, IL-5, and specific IgG, IgM, and IgE antibodies, leading to eosinophilia.

Clinical features:

  • History of travel or residence in filarial endemic areas.
  • Symptoms:
    • Dry, paroxysmal, nocturnal cough
    • Dyspnea
    • Systemic signs (fever, malaise, weight loss)
    • Peripheral eosinophilia (>3,000/mm³)
    • Extrapulmonary signs: Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly
  • Physical Findings: Wheezing, crepitations, organomegaly, enlarged lymph nodes.

Investigations:

  • Blood Tests: Leukocytosis with eosinophilia, elevated IgE, filarial antibody titers.
  • Stool Test: Rule out other parasitic causes.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest X-ray: Reticulonodular opacities, miliary mottling, or normal in 20-30% of cases.
    • Chest CT: Bronchiectasis, lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion in unclear cases.
  • Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs): Mixed restrictive and mild to moderate obstructive patterns.

Management:

  • First-line:
    • Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) for 21 days.
    • It targets both microfilariae and adults, leading to dramatic symptom improvement.
  • Adjunctive:
    • Corticosteroids reduce airway inflammation, particularly in chronic cases.
  • Alternative Drugs:
    • Ivermectin and albendazole target microfilariae and adult worms, though there is limited data.

Incorrect Options:

Bronchial asthma (Option A) is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to symptoms such as wheezing, coughing (often nocturnal), breathlessness, and occasionally fever. However, the presence of a miliary pattern on chest X-ray is not typical of bronchial asthma.

Miliary tuberculosis (Option B) is a severe form of tuberculosis (TB) in which the infection spreads throughout the body, including the lungs. It is characterized by the dissemination of tiny, millimetre-sized lesions throughout various organs, including the lungs, giving a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. The elevated absolute eosinophil count is not typical of miliary tuberculosis.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) (Option D), also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis, is an immune-mediated lung disease caused by the inhalation of various organic substances such as dust, moulds, or animal proteins. The absolute eosinophil count can be elevated in some cases. However, the presence of a miliary pattern on chest X-ray is not typical of HP.

questions.text: A 45-year patient working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Asbestosis

Explanation:

The clinical presentation indicates asbestosis, a form of pneumoconiosis caused by prolonged asbestos exposure. The key diagnostic features in this case include the patient's 20-year occupational exposure in a factory setting, presenting symptom of breathlessness, and most importantly, the HRCT findings of pleural thickening and fibrosis.

Pleural involvement is a characteristic feature of asbestos-related lung disease, distinguishing it from other occupational lung diseases.

Workers in the shipbuilding and construction trades, including pipe fitters and boilermakers, are occupationally exposed to asbestos.

  • Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung.
  • Past exposure to asbestos is specifically indicated by pleural plaques on chest radiographs, which are characterized by either thickening or calcification along the parietal pleura, particularly along the lower lung fields.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • Complications include carcinoma of lung and mesothelioma.

 

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option B) is characterized by small nodules diffusely distributed throughout the lungs, with upper lobe predominance and eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes. The presence of pleural thickening rather than nodular opacities makes this diagnosis less likely.

Silicosis (Option C) typically presents with multiple small nodules in the upper lung zones with a characteristic "ground-glass" appearance. The absence of these findings and the presence of pleural thickening make silicosis an unlikely diagnosis.

Berylliosis (Option D) presents with early-stage parenchymal nodules and later develops lymphadenopathy and interstitial fibrosis. The prominent pleural involvement seen in this case is not typical of berylliosis, and the exposure history doesn't suggest beryllium exposure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here?

choices.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • Chronic vomiting leads to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

Development of metabolic Alkalosis due to vomiting

  • Occurs due to a net gain of bicarbonate (HCO3−) or loss of nonvolatile acid (usually HCl) from the extracellular fluid, commonly caused by vomiting.

Generation Stage:

  • Vomiting leads to the loss of HCl from the stomach, preventing HCO3− secretion in the small intestine.
  • As a result, HCO3− gets retained in the extracellular fluid, leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis.

Maintenance Stage:

  • After vomiting ceases, the kidneys fail to appropriately excrete the excess HCO3−, maintaining the alkalosis.
  • This failure is influenced by factors such as volume deficiency, chloride deficiency, and potassium deficiency, combined with a reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Saline-Responsive Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • In cases of volume, chloride, and potassium deficiency, the alkalosis can be corrected by restoring extracellular fluid volume through intravenous administration of NaCl and KCl.

Saline-Unresponsive Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • In cases of hypokalemia due to hyperaldosteronism, the alkalosis may require pharmacologic or surgical treatment, rather than saline correction.

Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an increase in arterial pH, elevated serum bicarbonate [HCO3−], and increased PaCO2​ due to compensatory hypoventilation.
  • Often presents with hypochloremia and hypokalemia.
  • Occurs as a mixed disorder with respiratory or metabolic acidosis or alkalosis.

Clinical Features

  • Neurological: Mental confusion, obtundation, potential seizures
  • Peripheral Nervous System: Paresthesias, muscle cramps, tetany (similar to hypocalcemia effects)
  • Cardiovascular: Aggravation of arrhythmias, particularly in COPD patients

Electrolyte Imbalances

  • Potassium (K⁺): Hypokalemia, especially in cases involving secondary hyperaldosteronism or diuretic use.
  • Chloride (Cl⁻): Hypochloremia, frequently accompanying alkalosis, especially in cases of vomiting or diuretic use.
  • Calcium (Ca²⁺): Symptoms may mimic hypocalcemia despite normal levels.


Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350mg/dl, pH-7.2, HCO3-10, pCO2-30. What is the metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation: The patient has primary metabolic acidosis with partial respiratory compensation.

 

Stepwise Acid-Base Diagnosis:

Step 1: The patient's pH is 7.2 (normal: 7.35-7.45), indicating acidosis.

Step 2: The bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) level is 10 mmol/L, lower than the normal range (22-30 mmol/L), suggesting metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Use Winter's formula to calculate the expected pCO₂ compensation for metabolic acidosis:
Expected pCO₂ = (1.5 × HCO₃⁻) + 8 ± 2
For HCO₃⁻ = 10,
Expected pCO₂ = (1.5 × 10) + 8 ± 2 = 21-25 mmHg.

Step 5: The patient’s actual pCO₂ is 30 mmHg. This is higher than the expected range (21-25 mmHg), indicating partially respiratory compensation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema, and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Start IV fluids with a large bore cannula
Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
Take the patient to the ICU and intubate him

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a patient with respiratory distress, hypotension, subcutaneous emphysema, and absent air entry on the right side following a trauma, indicating tension pneumothorax. The next best step is needle decompression at the 5th intercostal space, anterior to the midaxillary line.

 

TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX

Pathophysiology
  • D/t ‘one-way valve’ air leaks from the lung or chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any escape, collapsing and compressing the affected lung.
  • The mediastinum shifts to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the opposite lung, leading to decreased cardiac output and function. This can result in sudden death.

Causes
  • Penetrating Chest Trauma.
  • Blunt Chest Trauma with parenchymal lung injury and persistent air leak.
  • Iatrogenic Lung Injury (e.g., central venepuncture)
  • Mechanical Positive-Pressure Ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Tachypnea and Tachycardia
  • Hyper-resonance and Decreased/Absent Breath Sounds
  • Resonant Percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
  • Cyanosis and Hypotension
  • Chest Pain
  • Distended Neck Veins
  • Subcutaneous emphysema

Emergency Management
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation.
  • Immediate Thoracocentesis (needle): Wide bore needle (typically a 20- or 22-gauge) in the 5th intercostal space in the safety triangle.
  • Decompression should be performed in the "safe triangle."
    • Safe Triangle Boundaries:
      • Posterior: Latissimus dorsi
      • Anterior: Lateral border of the pectoralis major
      • Inferior: A line drawn perpendicularly from the nipple to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line.

  • In critical situations, a finger thoracostomy can be done in the same location.
  • Nasal Oxygen for support.
  • Intercostal Tube Placement (ICT) once stable and confirmed by chest X-ray.

Additional Care

  • Antibiotics and analgesics for treatment.
  • Ventilator Support with IPPV in severe cases.

 

Start IV fluids with a large bore cannula (Option A): While IV fluids are important in managing hypotension, they do not address the underlying problem of tension pneumothorax, which is the primary cause of the patient's instability.

Take the patient to the ICU and intubate him (Option C): Intubation and ICU care may be necessary later, but delaying decompression can lead to rapid deterioration. Positive pressure ventilation without prior decompression could worsen the tension pneumothorax.

Start positive pressure ventilation (Option D): This is contraindicated in tension pneumothorax because it can further increase intrathoracic pressure and exacerbate the condition, leading to cardiovascular collapse

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows: pH=7.30, HCO3=10 mEq/L, paCO2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout

Explanation: The mechanism for the secondary disorder is Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout.

  • The arterial blood gas findings indicate partially compensated metabolic acidosis. Compensation is incomplete because the reduction in PaCO2 is insufficient for the degree of bicarbonate reduction, suggesting a secondary respiratory acidosis caused by hypoventilation. Hypoventilation reduces the ability to wash out CO2, leading to higher-than-expected PaCO2 levels.
  • The expected PaCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula:
    • Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 × HCO3−) + 8 ± 2
    • For HCO3− = 10 mEq/L:
    • Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 × 10) + 8 ± 2 = 21 to 25 mmHg.
  • The actual PaCO2 of 30 mmHg exceeds the expected range, indicating an additional respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation. Thus a mixed acid-base disorder is present, combining metabolic acidosis with respiratory acidosis.

 

Hyperventilation causing decreased CO₂ washout (Option B): Hyperventilation would enhance CO₂ elimination, leading to a lower PaCO₂, which would provide better compensation for metabolic acidosis. However, in this case, the PaCO₂ is higher than expected (30 mmHg compared to the expected 21-25 mmHg), which rules out hyperventilation. Instead, the findings indicate inadequate CO₂ elimination due to hypoventilation.

Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO₃⁻ (Option C): Increased tubular reabsorption of bicarbonate occurs as a renal compensation mechanism in response to respiratory acidosis, not metabolic acidosis. Since this is primarily a case of metabolic acidosis, increased bicarbonate reabsorption is not the compensatory mechanism here.

Increased excretion of H⁺ (Option D) by the kidneys is a compensatory response to metabolic acidosis, but it is a slower process that takes days to have a significant effect. This mechanism does not explain the higher-than-expected PaCO₂ observed in this case, which is due to hypoventilation causing decreased CO₂ elimination.

questions.text: The chest X-ray shows right-sided white-out lung and contralateral tracheal deviation. In which of the following conditions is this seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Thoracic mass

Explanation:

  • The radiological findings indicate a tracheal deviation to the side opposite to the white-out lung field due to a thoracic mass (mainly due to massive pleural effusion).
  • This pattern occurs when a space-occupying lesion or massive fluid collection (such as due to a lung cancer) in the thoracic cavity creates enough mass effect to push the mediastinal structures away from the affected side.
  • The pleural fluid is seen as opacity (single large black arrow) with lateral upward sloping of a meniscus- shaped contour.
  • The right diaphragmatic contour is also completely obliterated, indicating presence of fluid in the right pleural space.
  • In spite of a moderately large right pleural effusion, the trachea appears to be slightly shifted to the right side (as depicted by small black arrows) indicating an underlying lung pathology on the right side.

Pneumothorax (Option A) typically presents with a hyperlucent lung field without vascular markings due to air collection in the pleural space. In this X-ray, we see opacity rather than hyperlucency.

Consolidation (Option B) shows haziness or opacity on X-ray but maintains some visualization of underlying vascular markings. A complete white-out appearance is not typical. Furthermore, significant tracheal deviation is not a characteristic feature of simple consolidation.

Collapse of the lung (Option C) would show tracheal deviation toward the same side as the opacity, not away from it. This is because collapse creates negative pressure that pulls the mediastinal structures toward the affected side.

questions.text:
A male patient who is a known case of COPD presents to the emergency department with dyspnea. The arterial blood gas report is as follows:

pH: 7.28

pCO2: 60 mmHg

HCO3: 28 meq/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inadequately compensated respiratory acidosis

Explanation:

  • pH 7.28 is decreased, suggestive of acidosis, the pCO2 = 60mmHg which is elevated, hence the acidosis is likely respiratory.
  • The bicarbonate is 28 meq/L implying that compensation is partial (partial compensation/inadequate compensation)

This is a case of inadequately compensated respiratory acidosis because:

  • In acute respiratory acidosis, HCO3- will ↑ by 1 mEq/L for every 10 mmHg ↑ in pCO2
  • In chronic respiratory acidosis, HCO3- will ↑ by 4 mEq/L for every 10 mmHg ↑ in pCO2
    • In this patient, ABG shows:
  • pH: 7.28
  • PaCO2: 60 mmHg
  • HCO3-: 28 mEq/L
  • Normal PaCO2: 38-42 mm Hg

Thus, the difference in PaCO2 = 60 - 42 = 18 mm Hg

As this patient has COPD which is the most likely cause of respiratory acidosis in this patient, it is chronic respiratory acidosis

  • We know for every 10 mmHg ↑ in PCO2, HCO3- should ↑ by 4 mEq/L
    • For 1 mmHg ↑ in PCO2, HCO3- should ↑ by 4/10 mEq/L
    • Thus for 18 mm Hg ↑ in PCO2 , HCO3- should ↑ by 7.2 mEq/L
  • In this patient HCO3- should be approx 33 mEq/L, but it is only 28 mEq/L, hence it is only partially compensated respiratory acidosis

 

Incorrect Options:

Fully compensated respiratory acidosis (Option B): If this was the condition, the HCO3- should have been approximately 33.

Fully compensated respiratory alkalosis (Option C) is incorrect since the ABG in the given scenario is respiratory acidosis.

Inadequately compensated metabolic alkalosis (Option D) is incorrect since the ABG in the given scenario is respiratory acidosis.
